section.title: Interest Rates Components in Context
section.p: We are now going to take a closer look at factors that impact interest rates in both savings and lending products. We will first look at commercial banks, then government bonds, and finally corporate bonds.

There are a number of empirical facts that are in the SOA Study Note on Determinants of Interest Rates. These are often tested through questions asking which of several statements are true or false, and the questions could give you a series of statements and your selections could include one or more of the statements.

We will include some of the empirical facts in this activity, but cannot promise that they will be comprehensive. You are strongly encouraged to read the study note carefully (even for the problems in this text).

Let's start with commercial banks. These are the banks where you likely hold deposit accounts, such as a checking account. This is to be distinguished from investment banks (such as Goldman Sachs, for example) which are involved in more sophisticated transactions.

statement.p: Commercial banks offer two types of products - savings products (on which they pay interest) and lending products (on which they charge interest). How do they make a profit?

introduction.p: There are several factors that influence the interest rate offered or charged by a commercial bank. For each of the following, describe how the factor will impact the rate offered on savings accounts.

task.p: Overhead Costs: This factor consists of costs such as rent and utilities for a building.
Business Environment: This factor concerns that market in the region (which could be electronic) where the bank operates.
Business Strategy: This factor concerns the bank's strategic plans for growth.

Perceived Creditworthiness: This factor concerns whether depositors consider the bank to be a credit risk (waiting for FDIC insurance to cover your deposits in the event the bank fails is an inconvenience at best).

section.p: The two most common savings products banks offer are savings accounts and certificates of deposit (CDs). Savings accounts have few withdrawal limitations. Some limit withdrawals to a certain number per month. Others have no limits. For a CD, funds can only be withdrawn at maturity at the end of the term, otherwise the investor will incur a penalty.

Another family wants to put some money away to earn interest in order to make a major purchase in six months.

section.p: Let's now turn to loan products.
There are typically three types of loans offered by banks:

li.p: Secured Loans are loans backed by some sort of collateral. If a borrower defaults, the collateral can be seized and auctioned off to satisfy the debt. Home loans (mortgages) and car loans are secured.

Guaranteed Loans are loans guaranteed by a third party, such as the U.S. Government. The third party covers the lenders losses in the event the borrower defaults. Student loans are typically guaranteed.
Unsecured Loans do not have any collateral or guarantees. Most credit cards are unsecured.

section.p: We now turn to government debt (in the form of bonds). Debt issued by a national government is called sovereign debt, whereas debt issued by a political subdivision of a nation (like a state or city) is called municipal debt. Municipal debt is more likely to default than sovereign debt. This is because nations have the power to print money to satisfy their obligations (even though this is inflationary). In addition, some governments are able to link tax receipts to inflation. For example, the marginal income tax rates in the United States are on a schedule for anticipated inflation.

introduction.p: In the United States, sovereign debt takes the form of Treasury Bills (T-Bills), Treasury Notes, and Treasury Bonds. T-Bills have terms of 1 year or less, do not pay coupons, and are valued using simple discount (which we will explore in more depth later). Treasury Notes and Treasury Bonds are valued using semi-annual compound interest and pay semiannual coupons. Treasury Notes have terms of 2 to 10 years, and Treasury Bonds have terms from 10 to 30 years.

In the Unites States, income from T-Bills, Treasury Notes, and Treasury Bonds is taxable at the federal level, not at the state or local level. Municipal bond income in the United States are not taxable at the federal level, but may be at the state level.

section.p: Some Treasury Notes or Treasury Bonds are adjusted for inflation. Nominal Return Bonds are bonds whose coupon payments and maturity payments are fixed at the outset, with no inflation adjustment. Real Return Bonds are bonds where the face value and maturity value are adjusted for inflation. Since the face value is adjusted for inflation, coupon payments are also adjusted for inflation (but the coupon rate remains constant).

Typically, an amount is adjusted for inflation using the CPI. The amount to be adjusted is multiplied by the ratio of the current CPI to some base CPI. For example, if the base CPI is 120, and the current CPI is 132, then the amount is multiplied by 132/120, or 1.1 (which means 10% inflation between the base year and the current year).
The real return bonds issued by the United States Government are called Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS).

section.p: We now look at municipal bonds. There are two types of municipal bonds. Revenue Bonds are municipal bonds paid back with revenues from a specific project. General Obligation Bonds are municipal bonds paid back from the general fund and are not connected with any specific project.

section.p: Another factor that can influence the price (and yields) of government bonds is currency fluctuation, as illustrated in .

statement.p: A U.S. investor purchased a 9-month European bond denominated in Euros. The bond had a face value of 1000 euros, and was priced to yield an effective annual yield of 0.96% (European). The investor purchased the bond on January 1, 2020, when the exchange rate was 1.11 US Dollars per Euro. Nine months later, on October 1, 2020, when the bond matured, the exchange rate was 1.17 US dollars per Euro. Determine the US effective annual yield earned by the investor.

section.p: We now turn to corporate bonds.

statement.p: Corporate bonds are often purchased through intermediaries - brokers - who buy bonds directly from issuers and sell them to investors. Brokers make money by selling the bonds for a higher price than they purchase them. The amount that brokers purchase a bond for is the bid ("b"id for `'b"uy), and the amount they sell a bond for is the ask. The difference, ask - bid, is the bid-ask spread. The bid-ask spread can be expressed as either a price difference or as a yield difference.

The bid-ask spread tells investors something about liquidity. Liquidity is the ability to convert an investment to cash. If brokers expect it to be harder to convert bonds to cash (less liquid), the bid-ask spread will be larger. How will a larger bid-ask spread impact the interest rate on a corporate bond?

introduction.p: Several other factors impact interest rates on corporate bonds. Describe the impact of each of the following:

task.p: Rating. Independent agencies (such as Moody's or S&P) rate the creditworthiness of corporate bonds. The highest is AAA.

Seniority. In the event a corporation is liquidated in bankruptcy, some bondholders have a higher claim to the proceeds of the sale. The debt senior bondholders hold is paid off first, whatever is left is available for junior (subordinated) bondholders and other debtholders.

Call/Put Options. As we saw in , some bonds involve call provisions allowing issuers to retire the bond early. Some bonds have put provisions which allow the bondholder to sell the bond back to the issuer.

Corporation C has a high credit rating. They issue bonds with a high bid-ask spread, are senior to other bond issues, and have a call provision.
